column4: ive got 2.6.22-14-generic... the EXTRAVERSION in the Make file is set to = .9 ... so I need to change it to -14-generic correct?
if you're using the "old" approach to building a kernel, then you can use --append-to-version as well as changing EXTRAVERSION
i just need to compile a special driver... and the txt file im reading says to make sure the EXTRAVERSION in the /lib/modules/2.6*/build/Makefile matches the last part of uname -r
it had .9 and I changed it to -14-generic and was wondering if that was the proper syntax
Yeah, I'm not sure whether it is -14-generic or .14-generic
well thanks i guess I can try both if nothing else ;)
but, beware, you should build it with a _different_ number/code, as you don't want to build a new kernel with the same number as the one you're riunning
that will cause all sorts of problems
that is what I'm currently struggling with - working out how to set the right problem
basically, if you recompile to the same verison number, you loose the option to roll back to a known state
good luck.. if I figure something out, ill pass it on
im not worried about that i dont have  a previous state
i just want ubuntu to learn to speak modem
presumably you are running a kernel now?
if you recompile with the same version,but get something wrong, you could end up with a dead system
